identified-content.object.title: Ordinary Person's Guide to Empire, An (Book)

abstract.p: Anthony Arnove letter scores Jonathan Tepperman for 'ignorance' shown in Dec 12 essay citing book An Ordinary Person's Guide to Empire by Arundhati Roy; Tepperman response appended

block.p: Jonathan Tepperman ought to read what Arundhati Roy has actually written on the subject of ''anti-Americanism'' before committing his ignorance to print (''The Anti-Anti-Americans,'' Dec. 12).

But then it's much easier to dismiss her essays as ''peevish'' and ''strident'' than to engage in debate. In reality, Roy is a left-wing critic of American foreign policy and an ''anti-anti-American.''

In the very book Tepperman cites, ''An Ordinary Person's Guide to Empire,'' Roy writes, ''I, who have been vilified for being 'anti-American' and 'anti-West,' find myself in the extraordinary position of defending the people of America.'' She adds, ''American citizens . . . are our allies, our friends.''

Most who opposed the invasion and occupation of Iraq did so not out of some irrational hatred of American culture, but from a commitment to principles our government holds in contempt. And most of them did so, like Arundhati Roy, in solidarity with the many people in this country who share those beliefs.

Full disclosure: I am a friend and editor of Arundhati Roy and also her North American literary agent. I also worked (until two years ago) for South End Press, the publisher of her book ''An Ordinary Person's Guide to Empire.''
